thread.title: Victoria station roof collapse WAS caused by seagulls - and hub bosses blundered by not repairing it sooner - Manchester Evening News
thread.title_full: Victoria station roof collapse WAS caused by seagulls - and hub bosses blundered by not repairing it sooner - Manchester Evening News

author: Charlotte Cox
title: Victoria station roof collapse WAS caused by seagulls - and hub bosses blundered by not repairing it sooner - Manchester Evening News
text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Seagulls DID break Victoria Station ’s futuristic roof, the M.E.N. can reveal. 
Two passengers were injured after tiles in the iconic £44m structure collapsed and they were ‘blasted’ by a torrent of water in October. 
At the time of the incident, several sources told the M.E.N that the freak accident had been caused by gulls - drawn to the scent of the nearby McDonald’s - pecking at the roof panels and weakening the plastic dome. 
After a four-month investigation Network Rail have now confirmed the freak accident - when water flooded through the broken and buckling panel - was caused by seagulls pecking at it, causing visible damage. 
They have also admitted they blundered by not repairing the roof sooner. The probe found although staff knew about the faulty panel it was not reported effectively between Network Rail, responsible for the roof, and Northern , which manages the station. Read More 
Both operators say they have now ‘re-evaluated’ their communication channels when logging faults to ensure the incident is not repeated. A hole in the roof of Victoria Station, Manchester (Photo: Steve Allen) 
At the time of the incident, the M.E.N was told that the birds, whose pecking caused a torrent of water to ‘blast’ passengers below, had been attracted to the smell of the nearby McDonald’s emitting from a ventilation unit near the bubble-style roof. At the time, a spokesman said this was ‘highly unlikely’. The fast food outlet near the Arena has now been closed down.
